titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Sara and Gerald Murphy Papers
titlestmt.author: by H. Dean

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.physdesc: (196 boxes) + 21 broadside, 33 cold storage, 1 record album storage, 2 roll
did.abstract: The collection consists of the personal and family papers of Gerald and Sara Murphy, including material created and accumulated by Gerald and Sara, their children Baoth, Patrick, and Honoria, and the Wiborg family. The collection documents the Murphy's unconventional and artistic lifestyle and their role in the American expatriate community in Paris and Antibes, France during the 1920s and early 1930s, as well as their personal connections with artists and writers of the Modernist period. Also found is material relating to Gerald's father, Patrick Francis Murphy, and his stewardship of the leather goods company, Mark Cross.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Acquired by gift and purchased from John Donnelly, Laura Donnelly, and William Donnelly, 2008-2012.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.
Boxes 93-97, 169, 229-230, and 173-198 (audiovisual material) Restricted fragile material. Reference copies may be requested. Consult Access Services for further information.
Boxes 170-171 (clippings): Restricted fragile material. Reference surrogates have been substituted in the main files. For further information consult the appropriate curator.

Boxes 199-204 and 220 (photograph negatives): Restricted fragile material. Reference copies may be requested. Consult Access Services for further information. Preservation prints for reference use are available in the digital library.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Sara and Gerald Murphy Papers is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Sara and Gerald Murphy Papers. Yale Collection of American Literature, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The Sara and Gerald Murphy Papers received full processing in 2010-2011. At that time the Papers were organized into series and subseries based on provenance and formats. The Papers were in no discernable order when they arrived at the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library. Some material in the Papers was previously used by researchers and had been organized into subject files to facilitate this use. These subject files were not maintained during processing as they were not believed to reflect the ways in which Sara and Gerald Murphy created and maintained their documents.

Prior to acquisition a number of items from the Papers were featured in the exhibition "Making It New: The Art and Style of Sara and Gerald Murphy" curated by Deborah Rothschild and held at Williams College Museum of Art, Yale University Art Gallery, and Dallas Museum of Art. An item-level list created by Rothschild was consulted during processing for information about the use and provenance of several items. Amanda Vaill's biography Everbody Was So Young: Gerald and Sara Murphy, A Lost Generation Love Story and Honoria Murphy Donnelly's memoir Sara & Gerald were also referred to during processing.

Since 2011, addtional materials have been added to the collection. In February 2015 these additions were organized into five subseries mirroring the organization given to the papers during processing in 2010-2011.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: One exhibition catalogue was removed from the collection to be cataloged independently from the Papers and has a provenance note linking it to the Murphys.

relatedmaterial.head: Associated Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Mark Cross Company objects are also located at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

bioghist.head: Sara Wiborg Murphy (1883-1975) and Gerald Murphy (1888-1964)
bioghist.p: The lives of Gerald Murphy and Sara Wiborg Murphy are described in Everybody Was So Young: Gerald and Sara Murphy, A Lost Generation Love Story (Boston: Houghton Mifflin, 1998) by Amanda Vaill and Sara & Gerald (New York: NYT Times Books, 1982) by Honoria Murphy Donnelly. The following is a brief timeline identifying key events in their lives:
1883 November 7: Sara Sherman Wiborg born.
1888 March 26: Gerald Cleary Murphy born.
1912: Gerald Murphy graduates from Yale University.
1915 December 30: Sara and Gerald are married.
1917 December 19: Honoria Adeline Murphy is born.
1917-1918: Gerald Murphy serves in the U.S. military.
1919 May 13: Baoth Wiborg Murphy is born.
1919 September: Gerald Murphy begins his studies at Harvard University in landscape architecture. The Murphys move to Cambridge, Massachusetts.
1920 Summer: Reside at "The Glebe" in Litchfield, Connecticut.
1920 October 18: Patrick Francis Murphy II is born.
1921 June 11: Sail for Europe.
1921 Summer: Visit Croyde Bay, England.
1921 September: Reside in Paris, France. Reside at the Hôtel Beau-Site before moving to rue Greuze in October.
1922 June: Visit Houlgate on the coast of Normandy, France.
1922 October: Reside in Versailles, France at the Hôtel des Reservoirs.
1923 Summer: Visit Antibes, France and stay at the Hôtel du Cap. The Murphys befriend the Picassos. The Murphys and friends throw a "Mad Beach Party."
1923 September: Reside in Versailles, France.
1924 February: Reside in Antibes, France. Visitors include: F. Scott and Zelda Fitzgerald, Pablo Picasso and family, Donald Ogden Stewart, John and Katy Dos Passos.
1924 April: Reside in Saint-Cloud, France, at 3 rue Gounod.
1924 May: Frederic T. Murphy dies (Gerald Murphy's brother).
1924 June: Reside in Antibes, France.
1924 September: Reside in Saint-Cloud, France.
1925 March: Reside in Antibes, France.
1925 Summer: Move into "Villa America" in Antibes, France. Guests include: Fitzgeralds, MacLeishes, Rudolph Valentino, Dos Passos, and Stewart.
1928-1929: Reside in California.
1929 May: Reside in Antibes, France.
1929 October: Reside in Montana-Vermala, Switzerland.
1931 Summer: Reside in Bad Aussee, Austria.
1932 January: Reside in Antibes, France.
1932 Summer-1934: Reside in New York City and "Hook Pond," East Hampton, New York.
1934 Summer: Visit Europe.
1934 December: Gerald Murphy becomes President of the Mark Cross Company.
1935 March 17: Baoth Wiborg Murphy dies of meningitis.
1935 Summer-1937: Reside in Saranac Lake, New York.
1937 January 30: Patrick Francis Murphy II dies of tuberculosis.
1937 Summer: Visit Europe. Trip with Alice Lee Myers.
1938: Reside at "Swan Cove," East Hampton, New York and summer in Europe. Sailing with Dos Passos.
1939: Reside in New York City and East Hampton, New York and spend the summer in Europe.
1949: Reside at "Cheer Hall," Sneden's Landing, New York.
1964 October 17: Gerald Murphy dies.
1975 October 9: Sara Murphy dies.
1998 December 22: Honoria Murphy Donnelly dies.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Sara and Gerald Murphy Papers are comprised of correspondence, diaries, photographs, objects, artwork, audiovisual material, and printed material documenting the lives of the Murphy family and their circle of friends. The Papers also provide insight into Gerald Murphy's career as a painter. The Murphys' lifestyle is richly documented in photographs and various artifacts, which constitute an array of material culture. The Murphy Papers are a window into the American expatriate community in France during the 1920s, the creation of modern art, and the everyday life of a socially and artistically prominent family. The papers document the Murphys' friendships with a number of prominent authors and artists, including Ellen and Philip Barry, Katherine and John Dos Passos, Zelda and F. Scott Fitzgerald, Ernest Hemingway, Fernand Léger, Ada and Archibald MacLeish, Dorothy Parker, Pablo Picasso, Cole Porter, and Monty Woolley. The Papers also provide evidence of the Murphys' ancestors and their business ventures, including Patrick Murphy and the Mark Cross Company and Frank Wiborg and the Ault and Wiborg Company. The Papers document industry (printing inks and leather goods) during the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries.

The Murphys' upbringing, education, early travels, and courtship are documented in diaries, notebooks, and photographs. Sara Murphy's diaries, particularly those from 1898 to 1915, provide insight into her life as a young adult and her training in art. Her father, Frank Wiborg, kept detailed diaries that also give a sense of Sara Murphy's childhood and adolescence. Photograph albums record the family's travels, and provide rich insight into the Wiborgs' milieu as well as travel, photography, and customs at the turn of the nineteenth century. Diaries and photographs of Gerald Murphy during his adolescence, while attending Phillips Academy Andover and Yale University, are present in the Papers, although to a lesser degree.

The Murphys' everyday life, style, and circle of friends are documented throughout the Papers. Recognized for infusing the quotidian with creative flair, the Murphys' stylistic choices are represented by photographs and objects, which range from barware to costume jewellery to Mark Cross Company leather goods. Photographs of the Murphys' homes in the United States, France, and Switzerland, recipes in the Personal Papers series, and household goods located in the Objects Series provide insight into the Murphys' decorative tastes and talent for entertaining.

The Murphys' relationships are reflected in correspondence, photographs, and home movies, which illustrate expatriate life in France during the 1920s and the fate of the friendships over time. Fernand Léger is photographed visiting the Murphy family in Switzerland and the United States, and his collage postcards suggest his playful and intimate bond with the Murphys. The Murphys' correspondence and other documents provide evidence of their role as muses to their friends, for example, they were portrayed in F. Scott Fitzgerald's Tender is the Night , Archibald MacLeish's J.B. , and Ernest Hemingway's A Moveable Feast . Honoria Murphy Donnelly's diaries and notebooks date from her childhood and adolescence and provide a child's perspective of the Murphy family, including their frequent travels and circle of friends.

Both Sara and Gerald Murphy received artistic training and Gerald Murphy seriously applied himself in becoming a painter while living in France during the 1920s. Examples of Sara Murphy's artwork can be found in the Artwork series as well as tucked into the pages of her father's diaries, located in the Wiborg Family Papers series. Documents pertaining to Gerald Murphy's work as a painter can be found in the Artwork Series. Gerald Murphy's brother, Frederic Murphy, in correspondence with their mother describes visiting Gerald in his studio and provides a unique contemporary (and familial) perspective on his artwork. Material relating to the revived interest in Gerald Murphy's paintings beginning in the 1960s can be found in the Honoria Murphy Donnelly Papers Series.

The Papers also chronicle Gerald Murphy's careers in the military and with the Mark Cross Company. Gerald Murphy's experience studying landscape architecture at Harvard University is documented in his notes and sketches found in the Personal Papers series. His work to revive the Mark Cross Company can be found in the Objects series, which contains various Mark Cross handbags, some of which were designed by Gerald Murphy and are stamped with patent numbers.

The efforts of Gerald Murphy's father, Patrick Murphy, to transform the Mark Cross Company into a successful business specializing in luxury leather goods are documented in his papers, which include notes regarding advertising and merchandising, dating from the early twentieth century. Combined with the Murphys' collection of Mark Cross products, Patrick Murphy's papers represent various aspects of the Mark Cross Company's history.

Several documents pertaining to Gerald Murphy's brother Frederic Murphy (1885-1924) and sister-in-law Noël Haskins (b. 1895) are also present in the Papers. Frederic Murphy's service with the Tank Corps during World War I is documented in several series. These items give insight into American involvement in World War I as well as the perspective of an American soldier from training to deployment to post-war injuries. Frederic and Noël Haskins Murphy's lives in France following World War I are also represented in correspondence and photographs (located in the Photograph series).

Papers relating to Frank Wiborg, Sara Murphy's father, document his work as a partner in the ink manufacturers Ault and Wiborg Company. Frank Wiborg's diaries date from 1873 to 1914 and are a window into his rise as a businessman and the concurrent social and political status of the Wiborg family. The diaries are a record of a prominent industrialist family, who had homes in Cincinnati, New York City, and East Hampton, Long Island, and who were engaged in a number of civic organizations. In his diaries Wiborg provides insight into the daily affairs of the Ault and Wiborg Company and by extension the history of the ink manufacturing industry at the turn of the nineteenth century. Copies of posters for the company and Wiborg's treatise Printing Ink: A History with a Treatise on Modern Methods of Manufacture and Use also document the business.

Honoria Murphy Donnelly's work as an adult to recall, interpret, and preserve memories of her parents and her upbringing is illustrated in her correspondence, publishing projects, and collection of clippings. For example, Donnelly's book Sara & Gerald provides insight into her parents and family life. During research Donnelly interviewed a number of friends and family members, such as Hester Pickman and Noël Haskins Murphy, recordings of which are located in the audiovisual material series. Donnelly's work with a number of researchers interested in her parents and their circle of friends is demonstrated in her correspondence, collection of clippings, and audiovisual material. Donnelly's collection of writings by others based on the Murphys' lives illustrates the Murphys' enduring inspiration and fascination.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into ten series: I. Correspondence, 1911-1980. II. Personal Papers, 1884-1962. III. Photographs, 1880-1990s. IV. Artwork, 1897-1928. V. Objects, 1915-1967. VI. Audiovisual Material, 1932-1999. VII. Honoria Murphy Donnelly Papers, 1925-2003. VIII. Patrick Francis & Anna Elizabeth Ryan Murphy Papers, 1863-1931. IX. Wiborg Family Papers, 1854-1930. X. Additions Since 2011, 1880s-2005.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Correspondence is arranged alphabetically by name of the correspondent.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series documents Sara and Gerald Murphy's personal relationships, most notably with several prominent writers and artists, including John and Katharine Dos Passos, F. Scott and Zelda Fitzgerald, Ernest Hemingway, Fernand Léger, Pauline Pfeiffer, Dorothy Parker, Ada and Archibald MacLeish, and Cole Porter. While many of these friendships began while the Murphys were expatriates living in France during the 1920s, most of the correspondence dates from a later period, when the Murphys returned to the United States.

The correspondence attests to the deep affection between the Murphys and their friends, who sought their company and provided support after the death of the Murphys' sons Baoth and Patrick. In turn, the Murphys were dedicated friends. For example, their correspondence documents that the Murphys lent money to F. Scott Fitzgerald, so his daughter, "Scottie," could continue her studies at Vassar and to Fernand Léger so he could attend the openings of his shows in the United States. The MacLeishs' daughter wore Sara Murphy's wedding dress at her marriage ceremony and the Murphys were godparents to Dos Passos's daughter. The Murphys' role as creative inspirations to their friends is also evidenced by their correspondence. For example, Fitzgerald famously drew on Sara and Gerald in his novel Tender Is the Night , which he discusses with Sara in a letter dated August 15, 1935. Archibald MacLeish, who borrowed from the Murphys' lives in his play J. B. , sent the Murphys a copy of his sermon on the Book of Job (1955) which predates his artistic piece on this theme.

In their letters, postcards, and telegrams, the Murphys' friends provide a window into their own personal and creative lives. Ernest Hemingway discusses various hunting and fishing expeditions as well as his writing projects and creative routine. Dawn Powell interweaves narratives of her everyday exploits with descriptions of various writing assignments. Many of the Murphys' correspondents also discuss mutual friends, which similarly illuminates periods in their friends' lives, including illness, the loss of loved ones, divorces, as well as marriages and births. On occasion the letters themselves are creative pieces, such as Léger's humorously crafted postcard collages, Dorothy Parker's notes with clippings of bizarre lines from local newspapers, and Dos Passos' pseudo-military briefing sent to Sara during World War II.

The Murphys' correspondence with their employees, such as nannies (Henriette Géron, Ernestine Leray) and personal assistant (Vladimir Orloff), gives a sense of the Murphys' movements and activities. Sara and Gerald Murphy gathered around them an extensive group of friends, and while not all of them were artists or went on to portray the Murphys in artistic pursuits, these relationships provide insight into the magnetism of the Murphys.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The series is organized into four subseries: Diaries and Notebooks, Scrapbooks, Other Papers, and Printed Materials.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series contains material pertaining to the Murphy family's personal lives. Most notably, diaries, notebooks, and other documents, such as recipes, address books, and printed material, provide an intimate glimpse into the Murphy family's daily life. The series also includes material belonging to their sons Patrick and Baoth Murphy.

Gerald Murphy's diaries date to his life as a student at Phillips Academy in Andover, Massachusetts, and to his early years of fatherhood. Sara Murphy's diaries, while not continuous, date from 1896 to the 1940s. Her diaries represent particularly rich documentation of her interior life while an adolescent and young adult. Sara Murphy's childhood is also represented in her scrapbook of greeting cards, which dates from 1895 to 1897. The early years of the Murphys' marriage, and the birth of their daughter, are traced in Sara's diary from 1917-1918.

The Other Papers subseries contains a range of documents that chronicle the Murphys' lifestyle and friendships. For example, address books, calling cards, and business cards provide insight into the Murphys' various contacts and everyday life, particularly while they were living in France. The Murphys' recipes for cocktails and food are also found here and are suggestive of their reputation as artful hosts. Many of the recipes are annotated with notes about friends' contributions or culinary tastes. There are also a number of drawings by the Murphy children. Gerald Murphy's notes on landscape architecture, some housed in their original box, are also present and date from his period as a student at Harvard University.

Scrapbooks and printed materials illustrate the Murphys' pursuits and those of their children. For example, the paper "Auto-Gammier" roulette bought in France indicates the Murphys' musical interests. Among the printed materials are two pieces by Archibald MacLeish, Frescoes for Mr. Rockefeller's City and "Lettre d'Amérique Pour Gérard Murphy," given to the Murphys by MacLeish. The maps, brochures, and other travel information attest to the Murphy family's frequent relocation, and Sara Murphy's scrapbook of postcards indicates her early traveling experience. Patrick Murphy's collection of publications on hunting and fishing and Baoth Murphy's Bible with gun drawings and school publications are a window into their boyhoods. Similarly, Patrick Murphy's diaries, alphabetized "to do" list, and other notebooks represent his childhood and struggle with tuberculosis.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The series is organized into four subseries: Formal Portraits of Murphy Family and Immediate Family Members, Formal Portraits of Extended Family and Friends, Snapshots and Candid Portraits, and Photograph Albums. The two Formal Portraits subseries are arranged alphabetically by name of the sitter. Photographs of Sara Murphy as a child and young adult are in Group Portraits: Wiborg Family. The Snapshots and Candid Portraits subseries and Photograph Albums subseries are arranged chronologically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The two Formal Portraits subseries are comprised of studio photograph portraits of Gerald and Sara Murphy as well as their children, siblings, parents, extended family members, and friends. Photographs of Gerald and Sara Murphy in their youth, photographed with their families, are grouped with their parents' photographs. Most notably, the first subseries includes Man Ray's portraits of the Murphy family, Sara Murphy's engagement photograph, and a portrait of Gerald Murphy taken using a hinged mirror. A number of photograph studios are represented in the Formal Portraits subseries, including F. M. Somers, E. B. Core, and Marceau and Bellsmith (Cincinnati), Albin Guillot, Lee Miller , A. Sovignity, and Vallois (Paris), and Bachrach, Blackstone Studios, and Pierce (New York). Several of the Murphys' ancestors were prominent military and political figures, such as John Sherman, William Tecumseh Sherman, and Nelson A. Miles, whose portraits are included in the second subseries. The Murphys' friends, including Cole Porter, John Dos Passos, Ada and Archibald MacLeish, and others, are also represented.

The Snapshots and Candid Portraits and Photograph Albums subseries capture the Murphys, their friends, and extended family at leisure; for example, while traveling, attending parties, skiing, picnicking, sunbathing, and sailing. The Wiborg family was quick to adopt photography and thus Sara Murphy's upbringing is represented in informal photographs, some taken with Kodak No. 2 and Brownie cameras. As adolescents Sara Murphy and her sisters chronicled their activities at "The Dunes" in Easthampton, travels to California, Europe, and India, and created photograph albums that are a window into their lifestyle. Sara Murphy continued to create photograph albums as an adult, most notably capturing the Murphy family's activities from the birth of the children to the death of Patrick Murphy, spanning from roughly 1916 to 1936. A number of the photograph albums are wrapped in tissu de Provence. Over the years various photographs were removed from the albums, and when located, have either been placed back in the album or are accessible in folders accompanying the album.

Combined, the Snapshots and Candid Portraits and Photograph Albums subseries illuminate the Murphy family's day-to-day life, friendships, and travels. For example, photographs from the "Mad Beach Party" in Antibes in 1923, France, portray the Murphys playing on the beach with Pablo Picasso, Olga Picasso, Count Étienne de Beaumont, Countess Édith de Beaumont, Rue Carpenter, Ginny Carpenter, Gilbert Seldes and others. In 1932 the Murphys sailed their yacht, the Weatherbird , in the Mediterranean with Philip and Ellen Barry and then joined Ernest Hemingway and Pauline Pfeiffer at the L Bar T Ranch in Montana; both trips are represented in the Snapshots and Candid Portraits subseries. The photographs trace the Murphys' various homes and frequent movements, including relocation to Cambridge (Massachusetts), Antibes (France), Montana-Vermala (Switzerland), and Saranac Lake (New York). There are various snapshots showing the Murphys' homes, ranging from Sara Murphy's childhood summer home, "The Dunes," to the Murphys' later homes in Sneden's Landing (Cheer Hall) and East Hampton (Hook Pond and Swan Cove). Together the photographs portray the Murphys' way of life, from friendships to travel, home design, and fashion.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The series is organized into three subseries: Gerald Murphy, Sara Murphy, and Others.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Sara Murphy and Gerald Murphy subseries are comprised of artwork by the Murphys. Gerald Murphy's landscaping designs reflect his studies while at Harvard University. In some instances Gerald Murphy's drawings and sketches anticipate his full-scale paintings. The Gerald Murphy subseries also includes photographs of some of his paintings, including "Portrait," which is missing or destroyed. Murphy recorded ideas for his paintings in a notebook; however, this item is not in the Papers.

Sara Murphy studied art seriously as a young woman as her numerous drawings and sketchbooks indicate. Sara Murphy's self-portraits date from her courtship with Gerald Murphy and she continued drawing as a young mother, completing several drawings of her children. For the most part Sara Murphy worked in graphite, but also experimented with painting and etching.
The subseries of artwork by Others contains two drawings by Kenneth Conant and copies of Pablo Picasso's drawing "Le Cap Antibes" originally signed in the guest book of the Hôtel du Cap d'Antibes.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The series is organized into six subseries: Clothing and Other Accessories; Bags; Watches, Jewelry, and Eyewear; Household Objects; Children's Toys and Sports Equipment; and Other Objects.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of everyday objects that provide evidence of Sara and Gerald Murphy's lifestyle. The objects' significance range from the sentimental, such as Sara Murphy's wedding shoes, to the practical, such as household items and the splatter mask worn by Frederic Murphy in World War I, to the playful, such as children's toys and costume jewelry.

The subseries Clothing and Other Accessories consists of shoes, gloves, headwear, fans, belts, and handkerchiefs. The subseries also contains a black sequined mask, illustrating the Murphys' enjoyment of costumes. In addition to Sara Murphy's white satin wedding shoes, the subseries has a number of her fans, including French paper fans with graphic designs. Several pairs of Gerald Murphy's gloves are part of the subseries, in various styles such as leather Western gloves to white suede gloves, as well as alligator leather and embroidered belts.

The Bags subseries encompasses a number of styles, such as clutches, handbags, briefcases, and duffel bags, produced by the Mark Cross Company and stored within original merchandise bags. Most notably, the Bag subseries contains an iconic "feed bag" shoulder bag designed by Gerald Murphy for the Mark Cross Company (and stamped with his initials). Gerald Murphy's monogrammed briefcases and other business-oriented items are part of the subseries. The bags largely date from the late 1930s to the 1950s and are generally in poor condition for the reason that they were actively used by the family.

The subseries Watches, Jewelry, and Eyewear is largely comprised of traveling clocks, costume jewelry, and opera glasses. The traveling clocks, which fold into leather cases, are largely French made. Pocket watches, both made by the Mark Cross Company, as well as a Cartier wristwatch are part of the subseries. The Murphys' monogrammed cigarette cases vary in materials, and include one made out of tortoiseshell and others of wood. Necklaces, bracelets, brooches and several clips are for the most part made of semi-precious stones, glass, metal, and plastic, however some are made from pearls and gold. Feathers for Gerald Murphy's hats and monogrammed buttons, cuff links, collar buttons, and collar pins provide evidence of earlier periods of dress as well as the Murphys' interest in fashion. Sara Murphy's Mark Cross leather key pouch, and a hand-painted key ring are also part of the subseries. In addition to opera glasses, eyewear in the subseries consists of a pince-nez and folding spectacles.

The Household Objects subseries contains silver accessories, barware, tableware, and picture frames. The barware in particular is notable as it relates to Gerald Murphy's reputation for mixing unique cocktails. Bottle openers, corkscrews, a measuring cup, fruit presses, juicers, swizzle sticks, and other accoutrements attest to the Murphys' hosting activities. Table linens and napkin rings also provide insight into the Murphys' style. Leather-bordered picture frames and mirrors, produced by Mark Cross Company, provide further examples of Mark Cross Company goods as well as decorations from the Murphys' homes. Sewing-related material, including a pin cushion and various needles, straight pins, and thread, are also part of the subseries.

The Children's Toys and Sports Equipment subseries represents, in particular, the interests of Patrick Murphy. Of particular significance is a Tech-Bilt etching set with original etching pens, ink roller, and plastic plates with Patrick Murphy's etching of Ernest Hemingway in Western garb (the print is located in the Other Papers subseries of the Personal Papers series). A cartridge belt, complete with bullets, knives, and a compass, reflect Patrick Murphy's interest in hunting, fishing, and other outdoor activities. Hemingway, who taught the Murphy children to ski, gave the children a set of sealskin ski brakes, which are located in this subseries.

The subseries Other Objects is broad in scope and contains Frederic Murphy's splatter mask worn during World War I and a cigar box from Gerald Murphy's painting "Cocktail." Several items relating to the Mark Cross Company can be found in this subseries, including a lucite rendering of the Mark Cross logo as well as a plaque presented to Gerald Murphy at the centenary of the company. Mark Cross leather products, including photo albums and scrapbooks, are also part of the Other Objects subseries. Several items reflecting the Murphys' lifestyle are the flag and key for their sailing boat, the Weatherbird , as well as the printing plates and calling cards produced for the couple by Tiffany. Everyday objects found in the subseries include a miniature travel razor with razor blades, clothing labels, and whimsical dog collars in bejewelled and "black tie" designs.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The series is organized into three subseries: Phonograph Record, Home Movies, and Recordings Created and Collected by Honoria Donnelly.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The audiovisual series contains recordings created and collected by Sara and Gerald Murphy as well as by their daughter Honoria Murphy Donnelly. The only music included in the Papers is a phonograph record entitled "All the Way Home, Carnegie Hall Recording Co."

Among the most substantive audiovisual material is home movies dating from the 1930s and the 1940s. The Murphys created home movies, which, according to the labels, largely show the family in playful moments, such as visiting the MacLeish family for Christmas at their home in Conway, Massachusetts, sailing the Weatherbird , and playing at Saranac Lake, New York.

The subseries of Recordings Created and Collected by Honoria Donnelly largely consists of audio recordings of Honoria Donnelly's interviews while researching her book Sara and Gerald . Among her interviewees are the Murphy family's former employees, Ernestine Leray and Henriette Géron; her aunt, Noël Haskins Murphy; and family friend Hester Pickman. Also included are audiovisual recordings of interviews given by Donnelly and programs about family friends, such as Dos Passos, Fitzgerald, Porter, and Hemingway (to which Donnelly frequently contributed).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A note included with this audiocassette from October 8th reads: Dear Honoria, I feel fortunate to have had you all to myself for even those few moments this week. I hope I didn't go on and on about the ups and downs of this troubadour's emotional life. You were very sweet and understanding but I do get carried away from time to time. Thank God I have the ventilation of those wonderful songs or I would be intolerable company, I fear. I hope you enjoy the cassettes. I shall think of you on your amazing terrace listening to them and be very happy if they bring you pleasure. Love, Steve

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The series is organized into five subseries: Correspondence, Diaries and Notebooks, Other Papers, Writings, and Printed Materials.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series documents Honoria Murphy Donnelly's early life and later work to ensure the legacy of her parents and their friends. The Correspondence subseries contains Donnelly's exchanges with family friends, such Archibald MacLeish, while researching her books. The Murphys' connection to a number of authors and artists also resulted in Donnelly's role in providing interviews and facilitating researchers' access to her family's extensive archive, evidence of which can also be found in the Correspondence subseries. The resurgence of interest in Gerald Murphy's artwork is apparent in Donnelly's correspondence with various galleries and curators, in addition to several exhibition catalogues (located in the Printed Materials subseries).

Donnelly's diaries and notebooks, dating from 1927 to 1948, provide evidence of her family's excursions and way of life, such as their trip to Montana with Hemingway and sailing trips. The Other Papers subseries includes juvenilia as well as material relating to Donnelly's marriages and family life as an adult.

The Writings subseries consists of research notes, drafts, and other material that captures Donnelly's work towards her book, Sara & Gerald , in which she chronicles her parents and childhood, and her unpublished project Villa America Cookbook .
The Printed Materials subseries is comprised of Donnelly's collection of clipping files which document the Murphys as well as family friends.

did.unittitle: Patrick Francis & Anna Elizabeth Ryan Murphy Papers

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The series is organized into three subseries: Notebooks, Other Papers, and Papers relating to Frederic and Noël Haskins Murphy.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Patrick Francis Murphy was one of thirteen children born in Boston on July 25th, 1858 to Irish immigrants. After attending Boston Latin School, Murphy became a salesman for Mark W. Cross, a leather goods company specializing in saddles and harnesses. Murphy bought the company following Cross's death and continued to expand its production of luxury personal leather goods (a successful direction that Murphy had suggested that Cross pursue). Murphy served as a member of the Massachusetts Legislature from roughly 1887 to 1889. Murphy married Anna Elizabeth Ryan, also of Boston, and the couple had three children: Frederic T. Murphy, Gerald Cleary Murphy, and Esther Murphy. In 1891 Murphy moved his family and business to New York City where his business thrived and where he became popular as an after-dinner speaker. Murphy died from pneumonia in New York in 1931.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note

p.emph: Frederic Timothy Murphy (1885-1924) and Noël Haskins (1895-1982)

bioghist.p: Frederic T. Murphy was the eldest child of Patrick Francis and Anna Ryan Murphy. He attended Hotchkiss and Yale University (1908). After graduation Murphy worked for the Mark Cross Company as treasurer, general manager, and then secretary. In 1917 Murphy enrolled as a Private in the Sixth Field Artillery at Fort Myers and was sent to France in December to serve with the army and then the Tank Corps. Murphy was awarded the Croix de Guerre (1918), the Cross of the Legion of Honor (1923), and the Conspicuous Service Medal (1923). In 1920 Murphy and Noël Haskins married in New York. The couple lived in London and then settled permanently in France. Murphy died in Paris, France on May 23rd, 1924 from war-related wounds.

Noël Haskins, one of two daughters of Charles Waldo and Henrietta Havemeyer Haskins, was born on December 25, 1895. As a young woman Haskins trained to be a singer and was involved in theatre, performing with the Washington Square Players. Haskins continued to take voice lessons while living in Europe after her marriage. Following Murphy's death in 1924, Haskins moved permanently to Orgeval, France, where she entertained a number of guests including her lover Janet Flanner and sister-in-law Esther Murphy. During World War II she served with the Comité Américain de Secours Civil and was sent by the Nazis to an internment camp in Vittel. Haskins died in France in 1982.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series largely documents Gerald Murphy's father, Patrick Francis Murphy, and brother, Frederic Murphy, and consists of notebooks, correspondence, and other papers. Patrick Murphy's notebooks date from 1890 to 1931 (the year of his death) and contain quotes from newspapers and various witticisms, which were likely later used in his popular after-dinner speeches. The Other Papers subseries also concerns Patrick Murphy's role as a lecturer and includes drafts for his talks and an assortment of related newspaper clippings. Among Patrick Murphy's roles as President of the Mark Cross Company was marketing; this responsibility is represented in various notes and newspaper clippings that contain copy for advertisements (for the most part consisting of epigrams), printed advertisements, and directions for window displays.

The life of Frederic Murphy, particularly between 1918 and 1924, is traced in the correspondence he sent to his parents as well as a scrapbook created by his mother Anna Murphy. The material also relates to Frederic Murphy's wife, Noël Haskins, although to a lesser degree. The correspondence and scrapbooks cover the period when Frederic Murphy trained and then fought with the Tank Corps in France during World War I. In his correspondence Frederic Murphy discusses his experiences as a soldier, his health, family members (including Gerald's painting projects), and postwar life in France. Although Frederic Murphy died in 1924 the Papers include photographs of Noël Haskins Murphy from various periods, including her service with the Comité Américain de Secours Civil in France (in 1938) and at her home in Orgeval, France. Anna Murphy's scrapbook provides details about her son's military career, including letters, newspaper clippings, and photographs.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The series is organized into three subseries: Frank Wiborg Diaries, Other Papers, and Mary Hoyt Wiborg Papers.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Frank Wiborg, Sara Murphy's father, was born to Henry Paulinus Wiborg (1821-1867) and Susan Isidora Bestow (1832-1876) in 1855 in Cleveland, Ohio. Frank and his younger brother Harry left Cleveland for Cincinnati following the death of their father and their mother's remarriage. While in Cincinnati Wiborg attended the Chickering Institute, graduating in 1874, and began his career as a businessman. After various positions, including a stint with the Remington Sewing Machine Company, Frank Wiborg began working for Levi Addison Ault to produce printing inks. In 1878 the men entered into a formal partnership creating the Ault & Wiborg Company. Wiborg and Adeline Moulton Sherman were married in 1882, an event which Wiborg describes in his diary. Adeline was the daughter of Hoyt Sherman and the niece of William Tecumseh Sherman and Ohio Senator John Sherman.

The success of the Ault & Wiborg Company prompted its expansion to New York (461 Eighth Avenue) as well as Canada, Europe, South America, and China. Wiborg's business interests led to his family's relocation to Germany for a period in 1898, where the Wiborgs socialized with Kaiser Wilhelm II and his family. Frank Wiborg's travels through South America on behalf of his company resulted in his publication A Commercial Traveler in South America (New York: McClure, Phillips & Co, 1905).

Although retired, Wiborg continued to be engaged in his business, publishing Printing Ink: A History with a Treatise on Modern Methods of Manufacture and Use in 1926 (Wiborg was working on a second volume of the treatise at the time of his death). In 1928 the Ault & Wiborg Company merged with International Printing Inc. Wiborg died of pneumonia at his home, 756 Park Avenue, New York City, in 1930.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series contains documents relating to Frank Wiborg, Adeline Moulton Sherman Wiborg ("Addie"), and Mary Hoyt Wiborg ("Hoytie").

Frank Wiborg was a dedicated diarist whose journals cover his daily life from ages eighteen to fifty-nine (1873-1914) and trace his education and evolution into a prominent businessman. In his diaries Frank Wiborg records his observations of his family, his work life, and his involvement in society and politics. Wiborg chronicles his experiences as a student at the Chickering Institute and his early employment. Wiborg notes a number of important moments in his life, including his graduation, marriage to Adeline Sherman, the births of his three daughters, his involvement in politics, and his travels with General Nelson Appleton Miles.

Wiborg describes the family's everyday life, recording theatre attended and books read, as well as their lifestyle while living in Cincinnati, New York City, East Hampton, and Germany, and their travels (for example, in Europe and India). The diaries represent, through Frank Wiborg's eyes, the lives of his wife and daughters, and include various newspaper clippings recounting their activities and artwork given to him by his daughters. Clippings from a later period (1927-1930) can be found in Wiborg's scrapbook. The diaries contain Frank Wiborg's impressions of Sara Wiborg's life from birth until just before her marriage to Gerald Murphy and thus provide rich insight into her childhood and adolescence. Various ephemera are tucked into the pages of the diaries, including photographs, newspaper clippings, calling cards, invitations, ticket stubs, letters, and postcards.

The Ault & Wiborg Company is represented in Frank Wiborg's diaries, as well as in the Other Papers subseries, which includes two copies of the company's posters (one of which was created by Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec), and Wiborg's book Printing Ink: A History with a Treatise on Modern Methods of Manufacture and Use . For example, the diaries chronicle the development of the partnership between Wiborg and his partner Levi Addison Ault, the company's incorporation (1891), subsequent expansions, and day-to-day struggles, such as preventing the flammable materials used to produce printing inks from igniting.

The Other Papers subseries also includes Adeline Sherman Wiborg's recipe book dating from the year of her marriage. Papers of Susan Isidora Bestow Wiborg, Frank Wiborg's mother, can be found in her diary (written in the year her husband died), her Bible, and a letter from a cousin. Mary Hoyt Wiborg's scrapbook, "1904 Automobile Trip Along the Loire," chronicles the Wiborg family's travels through France as well as brief notes regarding the family's stops in London and Berlin.
